prayer: Dear Heavenly Father, I ask that You would help me to love others, for love comes from You. No greater love has anyone than he lay down his life for another. Forgive me for not displaying a Christ-like love. Amen.

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: If anyone with a weak conscience sees you who have this knowledge eating in an idol's temple, won't he be emboldened to eat what has been sacrificed to idols? So this weak brother, for whom Christ died, is destroyed by your knowledge. When you sin against your brothers in this way and wound their weak conscience, you sin against Christ. Therefore, it what I eat causes my brother to fall into sin, I will never eat meat again, so that I will cause him to fall. (I Corinthians 9:10-13) NIV
reflection: Christian freedom does not mean that anything goes. It means that our salvation is not obtained by good deeds or legalistic rules, it is the free gift of God (Eph. 2:8, 9). Christian freedom, then, is inseparably tied to Christian responsibility. New believers are often every sensitive to what is right or wrong, what they should or shouldn't do. Some actions may be perfectly alright for us to do but may harm a Christian brother or sister who is still young in the faith and learning what the Christian life is all about. We need to be careful not to offend a sensitive or younger Christian or, by example, cause him or her to sin. When we love others, our freedom should be less important to us than strengthening the faith of a brother or sister in Christ.
prayer: Dear Heavenly Father, forgive me for the times I have offended a brother or sister in Christ. Help me to always be sensitive to the feelings of those who are new in the faith. Bless all my friends with good health and safety. Amen.

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: Do you not know that in a race all the runners run, but only one gets the prize? Run in such a way as to get the prize. Everyone who competes in the games goes into strict training. They do it to get a crown that will not last; but we do it to get a crown that will last forever. Therefore I do not run as a man running aimlessly; I do not fight like a man beating the air. No, I beat my body and make it a slave so that after I have preached to others, I myself will not be disqualified for the prize. (I Corinthians 9:24-27) NIV
reflection: Winning a race requires purpose and discipline. Paul uses this illustration to explain that a Christian life often takes hard work ~ self-denial ~ and grueling preparation. As Christians, we are to be running toward our Heavenly reward. The essential disciplines of prayer ~ Bible Study ~ and worship equip us to run a successful race. Don't remain on the bleachers ~ don't just turn out to jug a couple of laps each morning. Train diligently ~ your spiritual progress depends upon it.
prayer: Dear Heavenly Father, I pray that Your Holy Spirit would continue to prod me on to the finish line ~ to that imperishable eternal reward. I pray that my goal would always be pleasing to You. Amen.

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: If you think you are standing firm, be careful that you do not fall! No temptation has seized you except what is common to man. And God is faithful; He will not let you be tempted beyond what you can bear. But when you are tempted, He will also provide a way out so that so that you can stand up under it. (I Corinthians 10:12, 13) NIV
reflection: Like the Corinthians we are living in a culture that is morally depraved with sin-inducing pressures. Paul has some encouragement He says: (1) Temptations happen to every one so don't feel you have been singled out. (2) Others have resisted temptation, and so can you. (3) Any temptation can be resisted because God will show you a way out. God will help you in resisting temptation by helping you: (1) Recognize those people and situations that give you trouble. (2) Run from anything you know is wrong. (3) Choose to do only what is right. (4) Pray for God's help ~ and (5) seek friends who love God and can offer help when you are tempted. Running from a tempting situation is your first step on the way to victory. (see 2 Tim 2:22) Remember temptation is not sin ~ Jesus was tempted three times in the dessert ~ Temptation only becomes a sin when you give into it ~ But in the same token do not flirt with temptation ~ like Paul says, run from it.
prayer: Dear Heavenly Father, give me swift and strong legs to run from temptation. Help me to truly recognize people and situations that would cause me to give into temptation. I pray for Your Help in Jesus name. Amen.

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: Therefore, My dear friends, flee from idolatry. Speak to sensible people; judge for yourselves what I say. (I Corinthians 10:14, 15) NIV
reflection: Idol worship was the major expression of religion in Corinth. There were several pagan temples in the city, and they were very popular. The statues of wood or stone were not evil in themselves, but people gave them credit for what only God could do ~ such as provide good weather ~ crops ~ and children. Idolatry, is still a serious problem today, but it takes a different form. We don't put our trust in statues of wood and stone but in paper money and plastic cards. Putting our trust in anything but God is idolatry, Our modern idols are those symbols of power ~ pleasure ~ or prestige that we so highly regard. When we understand those contemporary parallels to idols ~ Paul says we should flee from them.
prayer: Dear heavenly Father, I thank You for Your love and mercy. Help me to recognize when I began to place things above you. Forgive me for my sins of thought word and deed. Amen.

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: Is not the cup of thanksgiving for which we give thanks a participation in the blood of Christ? and is not the bread that we break a participation in the body of Christ? Because there is one loaf, we, who are many, are one body, for we all partake of the one loaf. (I Corinthians 10:16, 17) NIV
reflection: The idea of unity and fellowship with God through eating a sacrifice was strong in Judaism and Christianity as well as in paganism. In Old testament times, when a Jew offered a sacrifice, he ate a part of that sacrifice as a way of restoring his unity with God, against whom he had sinned (Deut. 12:17, 18). Similarly we as Christians participate in Christ's once-for-all sacrifice at the Lord's table when we eat the bread and drink the wine. This symbolizes His body and blood.
prayer: Dear Heavenly Father, each time I come to Your Table help me to remember to lay all my sins before you, so that I may be worthy of receiving Your gifts. Amen.

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: Paul says, So whether you eat or drink or whatever you do, do it all for the glory of God. Do not cause anyone to stumble, whether Jews Greeks or the church of God ~ even as I try to please everybody in every way. For I am not seeking my own good but the good of many, so that they may be saved. ( I Corinthians 10:31-33)
reflection: I believe what we should understand here is that Paul's criterion for all his actions was not necessarily what he liked best but what was best for those around him. The opposite approach would be: (1) being sensitive and doing what we want no matter who is hurt by it. (2) being oversensitive and doing nothing, for fear that someone may be displeased. (3) being a "yes person" by going alone with everything, trying to gain approval from people rather than God. In this age of "me first" and "looking out for number one, " Paul's startling statement is a good standard. If we make the good of others one of our primary goals, we will develop a serving attitude, thus pleasing God.
prayer: Dear Heavenly Father, forgive me for not always having a proper attitude. Help me Lord to adjust my attitude, that it would become more pleasing to You. Amen.

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: Now I want you to realize that the head of every man is Christ, and the head of the woman is man, and the head of Christ is God. (I Corinthians 11:3)
reflection: the phrase 'the head of the woman is man' does not indicate man's control or supremacy, but rather his being her source. Because of the fact that man was created first, the woman derives her existence from man, as man does from Christ and Christ from God. I would have to say, the principal behind Paul's words is submission, which is a key element in the smooth functioning of any business, government, or family. Why does there have to be submission? I believe God ordained submission in certain relationships to prevent chaos. But it is also important to understand that submission is not surrender, withdrawal, or apathy. it does not mean inferiority ~ because God created all people in His image and all have equal value. 'Submission" is 'mutual commitment' and 'cooperation.
prayer: Dear Heavenly Father, I pray for added wisdom and faith. I realize that I will never totally understand all that there is to know so I pray for added faith to accept what I do not understand. Amen.

verse: When you come together, it is not the Lord's Supper you eat, for as you eat, each of you goes ahead without waiting for anybody else, One remains hungry, and others get drunk. Don't you have homes to eat and drink in? Or do you despise the church of God and humiliate those who have nothing? What shall I say to you? Shall I praise you for this? Certainly not! (I Corinthians 11:20-22) NIV
reflection: When the Lord's Supper was celebrated in the early church, it included a feast or fellowship meal followed by the celebration of communion. In the church at Corinth, the fellowship meal had become a time when some ate and drank excessively while others went hungry. There was little sharing and caring. This certainly did not demonstrate the unity and love that should characterize the church, nor was it a preparation for communion. Paul condemned these actions and reminded the church of the real purpose of the Lord's Supper. How do you approach the Lord's Supper? Is it just something that others are doing so you follow suit? Or do you approach with a repentant heart? Examine your reasoning before you approach God's table next time.
prayer: Dear Heavenly Father, forgive me for the times I have given very little thought to the significance of Your Holy Supper. Help me to remember to seek Your cleansing each time I partake of the Holy Communion. Amen.

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: (one over lap from yesterdays Dev. ) If anyone eats this bread or drinks this cup of the Lord unworthily, that person is guilty of sinning against the body and blood of the Lord. That is why you should examine yourselves before eating the bread and drinking from the cup. For if you eat the bread or drink the cup unworthily, not honoring the body of Christ, you are eating and drinking God's judgment on yourself. That is why many of you are weak and sick and some have died. (I Corinthians 11:27-30) NLT
reflection: When Paul said that no one should take the Lord's Supper unworthily, he was speaking to the church members who were participating in it without thinking of its meaning. Those who did and still do are "guilty of sinning against the body and the blood of the Lord." Instead of honoring His sacrifice, we are sharing in the guilt of those who crucified Christ. In reality, no one is worthy to take the Lord's Supper ~ We are all sinners saved by grace. This is why we should prepare ourselves for Communion through healthy Introspection, confession of sin, and a true resolution of differences with others. These actions remove the barriers that affect our relationship with Christ and with other believers. Awareness of your sins should not keep you away from the Communion table but drive you to confess and then drive you to participate.
prayer: Dear Heavenly Father, help me to examine myself totally each time I come to Your table that I might not sin against You. Wash me white as snow. Amen.
